title: Monday, 23rd April, 2018

BE11:16am

This is all a bit of a scunner post March 12 numbers, where Clarkson didn't make any unusually cautious noises.

sprout always amazes me when FX moves cause warnings. If there's one thing an analyst can do without guessing its plug current FX into a model and study the variance.
Blank canvas morning all
GBKrona @ REF! - perhaps because re-cap means lower chance of bankruptcy?
Paper Chase < googles 'scunner' > Huh. My new word for the day.
BE11:17am

Now, the big question is whether this all represents a trend or a blip. Here's Liberum.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Volatility in financial markets and concerns about a possible trade war have supressed activity in shipping asset transactions. Faced with this uncertainty, many ship owners have been unable or unwilling to make significant short-term commitments to major transactions. We understand that activity in secondhand sale & purchase markets has been hit, in particular.

This has impacted the Financial division and sale & purchase activity in Broking. These are the less predictable parts of the group’s activity, with large swings in both transaction volumes and values possible. After a weak start to the year, it seems unlikely that FY activity levels will not be impacted.

Chartering activity has been more stable, reflecting the need for all ships to be employed at (almost) all times. However, freight rates in some markets, notably tankers, have been soft. Inevitably, this has made for a less helpful trading environment for Clarkson.

Finally, the weakness of the US dollar, in which the bulk of the group's transactions are denominated, has provided an additional headwind.

Mr Diamond Clarkson has become a gravy train for the senior exec's
Waterloo Bellwether for global activity though.
cracklenpop Huge sighs of relief in Whitehall as Kate goes into labour, removing awkward headlines about an imminent customs union showdown
BE11:19am

We have cut our forecasts to reflect the more challenging short-term trading conditions. 2018E EPS has been reduced by 25% and 2019E by 15%. The revisions are only in the Financial and Broking divisions, with slightly more of the total reduction falling in the former despite its smaller size, reflecting the greater bias of investment banking profits to transaction activity.

We have left our dividend forecasts unchanged. We see cover remaining more than adequate across our forecast horizon, with cash generation and the cash on the balance sheet remaining strong. The profile of our new 2019E and 2020E forecasts effectively shifts the earnings recovery profile a year to the right.

BE11:19am

The cut to earnings estimates is clearly disappointing, especially after the optimism on markets expressed by management at the FY results in March. However, we see the short-term challenges as reflective of uncertainty supressing transaction activity in asset markets, and the capital markets that fund them, rather than the result of a widespread reversal in freight rates. Indeed, we believe the long-term fundamentals for shipping markets remain attractive and compelling. Demand and supply should come into better balance as constraints on shipyard capacity and bank financing limit supply growth, with tighter environmental legislation likely to accelerate the scrapping of older ships. Clarkson remains well positioned to benefit from better market conditions, even if they are still not yet upon us, having deepened and broadened its capabilities to build an unrivalled market position.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

On our revised forecasts, Clarkson trades on a 2018E P/E of 31.5x and dividend yield of 2.4%. Although we continue to argue that Clarkson warrants a premium rating based on its market position and the potential to benefit from better market conditions, it is difficult to see a re-rating from current levels. Clarkson remains well positioned in its markets and long-term fundamentals continue to point to improved market conditions, but conditions in the short term are more challenging and seem unlikely to improve in the near future. We downgrade our recommendation to HOLD from Buy and reduce our DCF-based TP to 3200p from 3600p.

BE11:20am

Uh, I seem to have quoted that entire note. Apologies Liberum. They're house broker, by the way.

BE11:20am

There's also Panmure, making similar-ish noises.

#REF! I've been told its the Theoretical ex rights share price, I forgot it was a rights issue 3 for 2 rather than boring equity issue. Red face all around
11:21 am
BE11:21am

On our revised forecasts, Clarkson trades on a 2018E P/E of 31.5x and dividend yield of 2.4%. Although we continue to argue that Clarkson warrants a premium rating based on its market position and the potential to benefit from better market conditions, it is difficult to see a re-rating from current levels. Clarkson remains well positioned in its markets and long-term fundamentals continue to point to improved market conditions, but conditions in the short term are more challenging and seem unlikely to improve in the near future. We downgrade our recommendation to HOLD from Buy and reduce our DCF-based TP to 3200p from 3600p.

BE11:28am

Overall we view the reiteration of guidance for 2018 and the lack of incremental negative news as a mild positive. We believe the 5-year strategy represents a streamlining of the company’s businesses with a focus on where risk/returns will be maximized for Capita as a whole in the medium term - and thus should be taken well. Furthermore, the fact the company has stated clear targets on EBIT margins and FCF for 2020 is encouraging since it gives investors a reference point.

One concern could be on government services, which has driven a few negative surprises in the past and where there are still a couple of contracts under pressure. Failure to turn these around could pose a risk medium term, in our view. On new contracts we believe a consistent focus on risk/returns should help the company avoid future issues in this space.

BE11:29am

I'm a big fan of all analyst notes that say "the lack of incremental negative news as a mild positive".

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Another risk is on potential revenue attrition and its implications for margins and FCF for 2020. While management has said they have been conservative on the assumptions used, we believe Brexit transition for the UK continues to remain an element of
uncertainty that could have implications for Capita’s 2020 targets.

Overall we believe the reiteration of guidance for 2018 and the details of the strategy plan should be a welcome news to investors as a whole. However we acknowledge that 2018 and 2019 will continue to be key years where execution by management will be very important in order to drive further re-rating in the shares.

wayneJ Often the original stock lender does not call the borrow but the 'borrower' ie the shorter has to make the original stock lender 'whole' - in this case by delivering 5 shares where they had borrowed 2
wayneJ TERP = thereotical ex-rights price.
BE11:31am

They're neutral.

BE11:31am

Our 12 month price target for Capita is 208p derived byapplying 8x 2019E EV/EBITDA to our core estimates (70% weighting), and including anM&A component (10x EV/EBITDA, 30% weighting) and discount back by 10%.

11:31 am

However, very complicated and a costly transformation plan needs to be executed in market conditions that will remain tough

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Yep.

BE11:46am

PFC has once again reached our target price but this time we retain Buy-rating and increase Price Target to 670p (from 600p) due to a positive impression visiting PFC's core Middle East business. While Corporate overhang (SFO) & expansionary strategies (IES, JDS vessel) have de-rated the stock materially in recent years, Petrofac's core E&C business has continued to deliver and stands at the heart of a much more coherent & focused forward strategy, in our view.

wayneJ Capco still own Covent Garden? They have done that up well but one has got to ask how much more upside there? And will Earl's Court be a big hole?
wayneJ Nine Elms / Battersea does not entirely inspire one re cost overruns
BE11:47am

This is post going to look at some stuff in the Middle East. They enjoyed themselves.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

First, the engineering scale and complexity of projects undertaken by Petrofac was something we actually hadn't fully appreciated until we saw it in person. Second, the position of Petrofac as a top-tier EPC contractor, if not contractor of choice, is clearly true in core markets of Middle East & North Africa. Third, these qualities don't happen quickly or by accident or have been acquired via M&A. PFC has grown organically by building up a track record of delivery & capability through decades of presence in core oil & gas markets which creates key relationships and trust from both NOC and IOC clients.

BE11:48am

......... so, don't fret about that whole alleged thing.

GBKrona @BE - didn't GS have an upgrade on PFC too today? Any news on SFO review
BE11:48am

Whatever happens with SFO, this company is carrying on regardless and has a delivery history and capability which sets it apart in core markets. Oil & Gas remains the sector of focus but capabilities within that sector are increasing (Refining). Growth into new sectors is possible through engineering capability and JV-partnering (Offshore wind, Petrochemicals, reimbursable O&M). The same is true for geographical growth. Overall however, we were impressed with a strategy of incremental growth built on a foundation of project delivery excellence. We believe investors can take comfort with that when compared with past PFC growth strategies. We also contrast PFC's strategy & valuation against the "broadening" strategy of Wood Group acquired mainly via M&A.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

@GBK, yes. Goldman and SocGen also keen on Petrofac post the analyst trip.

BE11:50am

SocGen, I think, is an upgrade.

BE11:50am

We reiterate our Buy and raise our DCF-based TP to 719p (from 570p). Management re-affirmed that it is committed to maximising shareholder returns through a combination of financial deleveraging (low capex + asset disposals) and (potentially) further cost-cutting initiatives. We also see scope for consensus upgrades in the short term. Petrofac is now our preferred stock in the sector.

Virgin Money, I fear, might be on Friday's fantasy M&A note from Investec turning up in market reports over the weekend.

11:52 am
Virgin Money Holdings (UK) PLC (VM.:LSE): Last: 288.30, up 10 (+3.59%), High: 291.30, Low: 279.10, Volume: 1.34m
BintmeisterGeneral Where's a good home for cash right now?
BE11:53am

We’re not particularly good at identifying likely predators; rather, we prefer to simply focus on mispriced (potential) targets. We think that most recent M&A activity in the sector has had much more to do with “taking advantage of” valuation anomalies (e.g. TSB, Shawbrook, Aldermore) rather than placing any great reliance on “heroic” synergy assumptions. If this thesis is correct then (despite an attractive stand-alone story) Virgin could well be next in line? BUY.

BintmeisterGeneral I've got too much sitting in my account and I don't know what to do with it
Paper Chase @bintmeister I'll take it off your hands.
BE11:54am

Bloomberg ran an (unconfirmed) story earlier this week suggesting that Sabadell (NR) “is open to further acquisitions in the UK”. Regardless as to whether this is true, Virgin Money trades on just 5.9x 2018e EPS. We see the business profile as low risk, with (we think) a highly predictable outlook for returns, (against 0.8x 2018e tNAV we forecast ROTEs of 14.8% in 2018e, 11.7% in 2019e and 13.1- 14.1% through 2020-2023e). We expect the stock to appreciate sharply this year as EIR concerns recede and/or share buybacks loom into view. Otherwise, we see a high chance of emerging predatory interest.

BintmeisterGeneral @Paper_Chase that's very kind of you. Just give me the long number on your card, expiry date...
wayneJ @Bintmeister - Never Ever invest just for the sake of it. And never take tips from a 'chatroom' without doing your own work.
Blank canvas BE, thank you for Virgin Money

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Gist is that Brittain will suggest Costa will separate from from Premier Inn, just not yet.

BE12:01pm

I could quote Augustine of Hippo here, but won't. Instead, I'll quote Barclays.

BE12:02pm

Until now management has stated that it is open to the discussion regarding a separation but had been reticent to commit in this regard. We consider the Times article as suggesting management/the board has now moved to a more open stance and we believe a separation on a 12-month now is now looking increasingly likely.

As we first discussed in, What if?, 3 Jan 18 we see a group upside case of £47 and a ‘blue sky’ of £57 in the event of both a Costa sale (13-15x) and a full opco propco (4.5%-5.4% yields at 2.25x rent cover). We note that neither activist appears to be pushing for the Opco Propco scenario at this stage but they do believe that a separately listed Premier Inn could re-rate from current levels.

Valuation: 15.9x cal 18e PE/10x EV/EBITDA
